text:
Q: std::function and std::bind: what are they, and when should they be used? A:

A bit of necromancy, since this answer came up in my feed and it could use an update in 2025.

In C++23, you normally want to use std:move_only_function rather than std::function. This fixes a flaw in the specification of std::function that prevents it from being used in move-only classes (primarily std::unique_ptr). The class is still copyable if the underlying functor is. The implementation for function pointers, static operator() or lambdas with no captured variables typically has very low overhead.

When? When you need the same code to support multiple types of functor. (If you only need a name for the anonymous type of one lambda, you can assign one to a decltype expression with using, but std::function is simpler.) Without it, your APIs that take a callback need to be declared with a template like

template <typename R, typename T = std::ranges::range_value_t<R>, typename F = std::less<T> >
    requires (like_in_place_array<R, T> && // previously-defined concept
              std::predicate<F, T, T>)
R& sort_in_place(R& range, const F& predicate = F{});

// Call e.g. sort_in_place(arr) or sort_in_place(vec, std::greater<int>{}).

This allows the functors to be inlined. The trade-off is, it forces the entire library to be header-only. Each template is instantiated separately for each type of function object—or each individual lambda—you pass in, increasing code size and compilation time. Functions that hold different lambdas or types of functor cannot be stored in the same data structure. Having a type that can represent any strategy simplifies selecting one at runtime. A wrapper able to hold any invocable object in standard C++ solves these problems.

In contrast, std::bind and its family don’t do anything you couldn’t do with a lambda (and are likely to be implemented using them). I would only add to the excellent accepted answer that C++20 has std::bind_front and std::bind_back as syntactic sugar, which you might prefer to lambdas or std::bind expressions with _1 and _2.

Q: First Flutter default project: "File 'E:\..\merged_manifest\debug\out\AndroidManifest.xml' specified for property 'mainMergedManifest' does not exist" A: 
FAILURE: Build failed with an exception.

A problem was found with the configuration of task ':app:processDebugManifest' (type 'ProcessMultiApkApplicationManifest').
> File 'E:\task ajay\Flutter Apps\flutter_application_1\build\app\intermediates\merged_manifest\debug\out\AndroidManifest.xml' specified for property 'mainMergedManifest' does not exist.

Run with --stacktrace option to get the stack trace. Run with --info or --debug option to get more log output. Run with --scan to get full insights.

BUILD FAILED in 47s
Running Gradle task 'assembleDebug'...                             50.6s
Exception: Gradle task assembleDebug failed with exit code 1

ans:- android/build.gradle 4.?.? -> 4.0.2

    classpath 'com.android.tools.build:gradle:4.0.2'
    classpath "org.jetbrains.kotlin:kotlin-gradle-plugin:$kotlin_version"
}

and :

android/gradle/wrapper/gradle-wrapper.properties 6.?.?-all -> 6.4.1-all

distributionUrl=https://services.gradle.org/distributions/gradle-6.4.1-all.zip

Q: How to use PowerShell to switch default app (from pre-determined list) for a given file type? Windows 10 A:

I don't quite consider this question a fit for SO due to documentation of each constituent request being publicly available - this is more akin to a free bounty request. However, I'll endeavour to answer the question's content, irrespective, because the other answer answers the title.

PowerShell Script using NT Binaries

Although perhaps pedantic, if what you want is merely an executable script (which utilizes the PowerShell shell) to complete that task of yours, this appears to be a trivial task:

#!/usr/bin/env -S pwsh -NoExit

#> #### Open PowerShell Window
#`-NoExit` keeps the window open.

#```PS1
#Requires -PSEdition Core
#Requires -Version 7.4
#```

Set-StrictMode -Version 3.0

If ([OperatingSystem]::IsWindows() -Eq $True) {

    #> #### Show current Default
    #`assoc "$FileName"` displays the current association.
    
    $FileName = [String](Read-Host) #Enter `pdf`.
    assoc "$FileName" #This prints the application associated.

    #> #### Press Enter if OK
    #`$Decision = $Host.UI.PromptForChoice($Title, $Question, $Choices, 1)` provides almost exactly this. Unfortunately, it accepts 2 arguments, and I don't want to achieve this in a non-standard manner, considering that it'd be better to allow you to easily extend this to handle negative user choices.

    $Title    = 'File Association Verification'
    $Question = 'Is the previous file association correct?'
    $Choices = @(
        [System.Management.Automation.Host.ChoiceDescription]::new("&Correct", "Yes")
        [System.Management.Automation.Host.ChoiceDescription]::new("&Incorrect", "No")  
    )
    $Decision = $Host.UI.PromptForChoice($Title, $Question, $Choices, 1) #[Citation](https://stackoverflow.com/revisions/69098618/1)

}

It has deficiencies:

  1. I don't have Word available to me, so you'll need to write the association command yourself.
  2. Pinning to the taskbar programmatically using PowerShell doesn't appear to be (easily) possible in Windows 10 and 11, per this competent programmer's words.
PowerShell Script using PowerShell Commandlets

However, to modify this preference utilizing solely PowerShell commandlets is more difficult. It's certainly possible for me to construct such a script for you if the Registry values necessary to modify are publicly documented, as https://stackoverflow.com/a/76210885/9731176 explains:

File associations are kept in the windows registry, see Changing Default File Associations in Windows 10 and 11 for more information. You can use group policy objects for deploying file associations or just customize the windows registry records on your own.

However, they do not appear to be, and without that, that task becomes infeasible for me. Aforementioned is the best I can provide, and since it does actually provide what you ask (albeit maybe not what you want) I've posted it as an answer.

I'll take a look at HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\Applications when I can (as this documents) to see whether I can ascertain these myself.

Q: Facebook Device Login With Samsung Smart TV A:

I used facebook login with devices on Samsung Smart TV, it works, but only with partners facebook appID, i used appID from source code of test example.
Samsung TV doesn't provide any way to login yet. Preinstalled Facebook application uses old facebook rest api, which deprecated since 2012. All old applications, that was created befor 2012 has the ability to makes rest api request, but new applications not.
Summary: we don't have any official general way to login on Facebook. Follow updates for Facebook OAuth.
